title: Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah's charismatic leader for more than three decades, has died
summary: The head of Lebanon's pro-Iranian militia party was killed on Friday by an Israeli strike in his stronghold in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

title: Iran says Hezbollah leader's 'path to continue' despite his killing, Netanyahu says Israel 'settled the score'
summary: Hassan Nasrallah, who led the Iran-backed militia party for over 30 years, was killed on Friday in an Israeli strike on Beirut's southern suburbs. Biden said the killing was a 'measure of justice for his many victims' and later called for a 'ceasefire.'

title: Why Russia has decided to review its nuclear doctrine
summary: After having limited himself to making threats since the war in Ukraine started, Vladimir Putin wants to formally broaden the conditions for the use of his atomic arsenal. The announcement comes as a response to Ukrainian attacks carried out deep inside Russia.

title: French mass rape trial also takes place outside the courtroom
summary: Since the trial began on September 2, it has had an unusual atmosphere. Every day, Gisèle Pelicot enters the Avignon courthouse to the applause of dozens of people.

title: In Spain, Pedro Sánchez wants to counter the security narrative, highlights migration as 'synonymous with wealth and development'
summary: The Spanish prime minister, who advocates tolerance towards legal immigration, has signed agreements with several African countries aimed at managing migratory flows 'in a humane, safe and orderly manner.'

title: A spiral dive into Surrealism at the Centre Pompidou
summary: A vast and rich exhibition at the Centre Pompidou in Paris reveals a new history of the movement launched 100 years ago, but not without a few omissions and blunders.

title: 'Harlequin,' Lagy Gaga's recreational album based on her 'Joker' character
summary: The American singer and actress, starring in the film 'Joker: Folie à deux,' in cinemas October 2, returns with an album of covers – and two previously unreleased tracks – lacking any clear musical direction.

title: Harris visits border to neutralize weak spot against Trump
summary: The US vice president's trip to Arizona – her first to the border since replacing President Joe Biden as Democratic nominee in July – comes as polls show the subject remains one of her biggest vulnerabilities against Trump.

title: Archives suggest not only the Church knew about Abbé Pierre's sexual assaults
summary: The archives of the French Catholic Church, which Le Monde was able to consult, suggest that various people were aware of the priest's deviant behavior.

title: Macron uses international spotlight to pivot away from French politics
summary: On a trip to Canada on Thursday, the French president did his utmost to distance himself from choices made by Prime Minister Michel Barnier. A way of trying to minimize his responsibility should the current government be toppled.

title: French mass rape trial: Defendants claim they didn't 'intend' to rape Gisèle Pelicot
summary: Nine of Dominique Pelicot's 50 co-defendants have testified. They all put forward the same defense, claiming that they had been 'manipulated' and did not realize that the victim was unconscious due to the drugs her husband was secretly administering.

title: In Japan, defense specialist Shigeru Ishiba is set to become prime minister.
summary: The former Minister of Defense and Agriculture has been elected head of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party. He will succeed Fumio Kishida as prime minister. He campaigned on transparency of political financing, strengthening Japan's defense and developing regional economies.

title: In Austria, the migration issue has dominated the general election campaign
summary: The Alpine country is one of the highest per capita refugee-receiving countries in the EU. But leading in the polls today, the far right is promising to 'stop the right of asylum' and is brandishing the racist theory of the 'great replacement.'

title: Donald Trump again accuses American Jews of disloyalty
summary: The Republican candidate in the November presidential election criticized Jewish voters for mostly voting 'for the enemy.'

title: Diving into the black box of global pesticide propaganda
summary: Bonus Eventus files (2/3). Created by former Monsanto communications director Jay Byrne, the private Bonus Eventus platform provides its members with a vast list of pro-agrochemical propaganda designed to influence public debate.

title: Vladislav Inozemtsev, Russian economist and dissident: 'Today's sanctions against Russia will be felt in several years'
summary: In exile since 2023, the researcher says Russia's economy is in good shape, far from being affected in the short term by the sanctions imposed by the West after its war in Ukraine.

title: Ukraine's Zelensky 'grateful' for 'productive meeting' with Trump
summary: Coming after clashes sparked off when Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Trump 'doesn't really know how to stop the war,' the meeting between the two ended with a press conference at which Trump reminded reporters of Zelensky's support.

title: Maggie Smith, unforgettable actress from 'Downton Abbey' and 'Harry Potter,' has died
summary: She never stopped acting, starring in 100 plays and nearly 60 feature films. An impressive career that made her one of the most highly regarded British actresses. She has died at the age of 89.

title: 'In the southern suburbs of Beirut, it's getting worse; we've seen some very intense bombings ... we'd rather go to Syria'
summary: At the Masnaa border crossing, around 30,000 people in three days, mainly women and their children, have fled from Israeli strikes in Lebanon to take refuge in Syria.

title: How Trump's administration used influence and misinformation campaigns to torpedo EU Green Deal
summary: Bonus Eventus Files (3/3). In 2020, as Europe announced an ambitious policy to make its agriculture more sustainable, the Trump administration decided to go on the attack. In its crusade, it recruited the influence firm v-Fluence founded by a former Monsanto executive.

title: Who are Russia's 'illegal' spies?
summary: Secret agents in Russia's 'illegals' program, launched during the 1930s under Stalin,  live under elaborate false identities for many years. Le Monde tells the story of two of these spies who were recently unmasked.
